item.description:
The game is afoot as you leave Holmes’ apartment at 221-B Baker Street and make your way through London and The Country to solve a mysterious case. Travel about by Train or Hansom Cab to visit locations like Scotland Yard, the West End, a Country Village, or return to Baker Street where interesting twists ensue.

Players will find clues, receive telegrams, don disguises, call the local constabulary, deal with inspectors, and name suspects in their pursuit to discover and arrest the villains who are hiding in other player’s card hands.

Are you a mastermind who can find a villain like Professor Moriarty, or will he manage to flee England and escape?

Time scale: Each game equals one case that is chock full of movement, locations, information, suspicion and action.

link.value: I Say Holmes!: The Plot Thickens

name.value: Stop Light:The Amazing Magnetic Maze Game

item.description:
Stop Light is the amazing magnetic maze game. Magnetic traffic lights change like magic at any of 100 intersections.

There are two ways to play. In the first a card is drawn and the first person to get their car to the location first wins that card. Another card is then drawn and play continues in this fashion until all 18 cards have been collected. The winner is the person with the most cards. The alternate way to play is the Cross Town game. The cards are not used in this one and the winner is first player to cross town by hitting the fewest red lights.

Magnets are placed in the plastic base according to the instructions and then the game board is placed on the base. As the players car moves on the board the magnet in the bubble in the car may flip from red to green depending on the magnetic action caused by the base.

Up to 6 players try to create the biggest and worthiest flower carpet in this tactical tile laying game. They have 91 flower tiles at their disposal. There are multicolored joker tiles called "Serendips" that allow making more victory points. Playing those tiles and adding the ones of the own color as foresighted as possible is the key to victory.

The rules booklet contains the following languages: D–GB–F–NL–I

name.value: Scrabble Junior: Dora the Explorer Edition
Dora the Explorer My First Scrabble

item.description:
Explore the magic of wordplay with Dora and her friends. Play your very first game of scrabble with Dora and her friends. Learn simple words in English and Spanish. Teaches word building and letter recognition. Two different games and two levels of play for both younger and older kids. Features double sided board, double sided cards and auto-corrective tiles.

This edition of Scrabble Junior has a two-sided board, one for English words and one for Spanish words. The rules play similarly to other editions of Scrabble Junior. The goal is to lay down letter tiles one at a time to complete words pre-printed on the board. Letter tiles are played twice per turn, and must be used from the beginning of each word and sequentially toward the end. All tiles are face up once held by a player. Kids learn the strategy of maximizing point values for themselves while preventing points for other players. They also learn its okay if other players do earn points because of the rules that a letter must be played if a space is available to play it on. Players use all the tiles available to cover all of the spaces on the board.

The game scales are Column-Brigade-Division, with monthly turns. There are Corps HQs for the Nationalists and Army HQs for the Republic. There are one 22" x 17"map, and two ½" counter sheets including Nationalist, Republicans, Italian, French, German, Portuguese and British units. The sequence of play is quite classic: Mutual Administrative Phase (Events, replacements, reinforcements, withdrawals), Nationalist Movement-Combat, Republican Movement-Combat, Victory/Attrition Phase. Supply is checked for both sides at the end of each turn.

The main trouble designing this game was how to simulate the first months of the war and the transition to a more conventional conflict during and after the battles for Madrid (October 1936-March 1937). The main unit during the firsts stages of the war was the "column" formed by a mix of police, army, paramilitary forces, volunteers, etc. The "column" tactics was used during the Moroccan wars, and consisted in separating a force in small independent groups, highly mobile but with few possibilities of supporting each other. These tactics were mostly used by the Nationalists, but also by the Republicans. For the Nationalists, it worked against the militias of the early months of the war but failed against a better organized, armed and commanded army during the battles for Madrid. To simulate this, most early Republican units have two steps: the first would be the "column" or "militia" side, the second the "Ejército Popular" (People’s Army) side. After passing a "Conversion" or "Militarization" phase, the Republican columns are flipped to their EP side. The "Militarization" , that began during the Fall of 1936, was the conversion of the politically enthusiastic but poorly led and trained militia in more orthodox military units. The Nationalist columns are divided between "Army of Africa" columns and the rest. Their colonial units are two-steppers and are withdrawn and substituted by brigades and divisions during 1937. The O.B. of the first months of the war is also a problem. Between July and November 1936 both sides formed dozens of small military and paramilitary units, called "battalions", "columns", "regiments", etc., etc. It is rare to find two authors that have the same OB, and the few that offer an Order of Battle are rather imprecise. Sometimes the same column receives different names. One author names it after their commander, other after their area of operations, and so on... so I had to compare and check which column was cited in most of the sources.

item.description:
AppLEOpoly is a promotional game published by the Leo Burnett Company, Inc to give to their employees on their 54th anniversary. The game is basically a Monopoly clone but with a few differences. For example, the house rule of collecting money when landing on Free Parking is an actual rule in AppLEOpoly. (The space is called "Free Coffee.")

The name comes from Leo Burnett Company's tradition of leaving Apples at the reception desk for visitors. Consequentially, the "Go" space on the board is called "Reception Desk" and is illustrated with a bowl of Apples." Other squares are accounts that the company holds. The "Jail" square is called "Working Weekend."

Greater Miamiopoly is a clone of Monopoly. The real estate squares are all advertisements for Miama businesses, sports teams, and media. This game used to be given away by the Miami Herald as a business present.

From the manufacturer:

Players adopt puppies as they make their way around the board. Woof! Woof! Little kid game play includes barking the number of treats owed when landing on a space, “high pawing” other players, balancing treats on noses. This is a younger version of a property trading game where FUN is the rule and silliness is a must! Flip the deeds over and learn a fun fact about each breed and a puppy training tip too!

For ages 5 to 8.

link.value: Late for the Sky Production Company

item.description:
From the manufacturer:

Players collect ponies as they make their way around the board and “TAP! TAP!’ with their imaginary hooves the number of treats owed when another player lands on their pony. Game play includes “High Hoofing” other players and collecting horseshoes. This is a younger version of a property trading game where it’s SNORTS AND GIGGLES until someone gets sent to the Stable! The deed for each pony contains fun facts about the breed and helpful pony tips too!

2 – 4 players, ages 5 – 8

link.value: Late for the Sky Production Company

item.description:
From the manufacturer:

If you’re looking for outstanding academics, an active collegiate social life, big time college sports, all wrapped in a beautiful Appalachian setting, West Virginia University is the place for you. WVU is a top choice for scholars, researchers, and athletes. Located in the picturesque mountains of north-central West Virginia, the university is the state’s flagship land-grant college.

We visited Morgantown, West Virginia and asked students and alumni, “What makes this place so great?” We spent time lounging in the Lair, listening to stories about WVU legends, Rhodes scholars, athletic prowess, the best pizza in town, etc. We strolled around campus and watched the sun set on the Monongahela River. We even took a ride on the futuristic PRT. The result of all this intense research? A game so full of WVU, we could hardly get the lid on!

item.description:
Content:
4 robbers (wooden),
1 policeman,
die,
board

4 robbers heavily loaded with valuable treasures try to creep home through the forest. But the path to the robbers' cave is not easy to travel, because the gendarme are already following them. Will the robbers be able to bring their treasures home safely? Everyone tries to bring its robber with the accumulated valuable treasure to the hiding place first.

Content:
100 share-cards
8 cash cards

The players try by skillful trading and exchanging to get as many shares of the company as possible.
The more shares you own, the higher is your total value.

Content:
board,
100 Nessy parts(head, belly, tail)
1 die,

In the course of the game everyone tries to let develop complete Nessys on the board. A Nessy consists of one head, 1 to 5 bulging out center sections and tail. If a player throws a color and has no more Nessy parts, the game is over. The highest number of completed Nessys determines the winner.

Content:
board, 11 dwarves, 1 Giant, 7 bushes, 1 special die,

4 pairs of dwarves must try to safely get themselves into the cave on the mountain summit with their jewels before the giant Grobian has reached it. If at least 4 dwarves, one from each color, succeed in reaching the jewel cave, the dwarves beat the giant and win.

This is a game intended to teach children about dogs. The rulebook has a general information section on dogs, including what meaning of different behavior in dogs, what an angry/scared dog looks like, and how to teach children about dogs. Sometimes, the rules instruct the players to act dog like (barking, rolling etc.)

The game includes a board with an imaginary village printed on it, 4 playing pieces (dogs) on plastic bases, a deck of cards which represent 24 breeds of dog - some of which are "leaders" - and one 6-sided die. All of the dogs belong to families living in the village, identified by the first letter of a dog's name.

The game is subdivided into 6 different variants:

Game #1: 2-4 players, 10-15 minutes. This is described as a "warm-up" game, the board is not used. Players are "leader" dogs trying to gather their own pack by drawing cards blindly. The player with the most dogs after all non-leader breeds have been drawn wins.

This game also has a solitaire variant.

Game #2: 2-4 players, 30 minutes. Again, the players represent leaders trying to gather a pack. This is accomplished by visiting the 4 houses in the village to pick up dogs, then take them to the dog park.

This game has rule variants to make it a bit more challenging.

Game #3: 2-4 players, 20-30 minutes. Again, the players represent leaders, but this time they already have a pack. The players must return the dogs in their pack to the families, then find a way to their own house.

Game #4: 3 or more players, 10-20 minutes. This time the players must co-operate to gather a pack and take it to the dog park, playing against time (die rolls).

This game also has a solitaire variant.
 Game #5: 2-4 players, 20-30 minutes. This is basically a version of the Game of Authors - players are trying to complete series of dogs belonging to the same family.

Game #6: Solitaire, variable playing time. The aim is to rescue dogs from the kennel by pairing up the kennel dogs with free dogs.

Description from Uncles Games:

"Similar to Scrabble, players are creating word puzzles in a crossword fashion, only with Saygo, you do not have a community board. Instead, players builds their own word puzzles in front of them. Letters are worth points (vowels are worth 1 point, consonants 2 points, and super consonants J, K, Qu, X, and Z, are worth 4) the object of the game is to be the first player to reach 500 points. Every player randomly selects eight tiles and places them face down. Simultaneously, players turn them over and begin building the puzzles with as many letters from their individual pile as possible. Once someone has used up all eight tiles, he or she says "Saygo" and all players will select another tile. If nobody can use their tiles it is a stalemate, and everyone selects another tile. Should players find they can not use all of their tiles, they have the option of rearranging their puzzles as often as needed, in attempt to use all letters. The game continues until all tiles are used and the last person to use his/her last tile yells "done". Once the group verifies the accuracy of the winning player's words, the winner collects the remaining letters and adds them to his/her score. Once a player has 500 points (that number can be lowered or raised if desired), the round is finished and players can play again."

This is a children's game based on the fairy-tales by the Brothers Grimm.

It comes with a colorful board, 36 story tiles, 4 player pawns and a six-sided die. The rulebook also contains the nine stories found in the game.

Players roll to move their pawns along the track, collecting sets of tiles.

From the box cover:

Märchenland - "Das Spiel mit 9 berühmten Märchen de Gebrüder Grimm"

And on the back of the box:

Die Spieledee
"Es war einmal ein Zauberwald. Dort machten sich lustige kleine Zwerge auf den Weg nach 9 Märchen der Gebrüder Grimm zu suchen. Seit vielen Jahren hält in dem Zauberwald eine Fee die Märchen in ihrem Bann.
Nun gilt es, diese 9 Märchen zu befreien. Manchmal auch mit Unterstützung des Zauberstables. Auf geht's ihr flinken Zwerge und huscht durch Zauberwald!"

name.value: A Tour Through the British Colonies and Foreign Possessions

item.description:
A Tour Through The British Colonies and Foreign Possessions is from an original hand coloured lithographic game published in about 1850 by John Betts of London. The game is a whistle-stop tour around the world from London via Africa, India, Japan, the West Indies, the United States of America, Canada, and finally, a race back to London. The first part of the journey includes the choice of two routes. The overland journey visits the city of Alexandria and the sea cruise calls in at Sierra Leone and the Cape.

With 36 stops along the route, the visitor participates in a remarkable, colonial experience of the world.

The game includes a box, mounted color map, reproduction rule book and catalog, The Historical Games Collection catalog, four re-created pawns lightly tipped in colors, and a six sided teetotum (spinner - dice were considered at the time as something used for gambling).

Game play involves spinning, moving your pawn the appropriate number of spaces, and then reading the educational paragraph about the colony or possession you have landed on.

The reproduction edition's rulebook notes: "These rules are copied directly from the originals and reflect the moral and social outlook of early 19th century imperialist peoples. The facts and attitudes are often wrong, intolerant and patronizing and should be read from a historical perspective."

name.value: The Noble Game of Elephant and Castle or Travelling in Asia

item.description:
The Noble Game of Elephant and Castle was first published in 1822 as a hand coloured engraving by William Darton of London.

The game is played on a magnificent board depicting an elephant surmounted by a howdah (ornate carriage) with an Indian mahout (driver). The mysteries of the Orient are discovered through a grand tour from the Frozen Ocean in the Arctic wastes of north Russia thence south through Asia into India, China, and Japan. The game was published at the height of the British Empire and outrageously describes the appearance, customs and culture of the region's peoples, comparing their way of life to that of the British.

The game comes in a box with a mounted full color reproduction board, reproduction rules, Catalog of The Historical Games Collection, four "travelers" (pawns) - each lightly tipped with a different color, 16 counters (chips, each with the rose face lightly colored to match pawns), and a teetotum (top with eight sides, numbered 1-8 - dice being items of gambling).

Each player spins and moves their pawn a number of spaces, attempting to progress to 25 by exact count. Each space has a description in the accompanying rule book to be read aloud, describing the scene from an area of Asia. The counters are used to mark off missed turns assigned by the descriptions.

The rules note: "These rules are copied directly form the originals and reflect the moral and social outlook of early 19th century imperialist peoples. The facts and attitudes are often wrong, intolerant and patronizing and should be read from a historical perspective."

From the manufacturer:

Cast off on an excursion that’s fun from the time you leave the dock till you head back to shore! This is a game for those who REALLY reel in the big ones... or those who just dream big.

Buy your properties and then increase the value by adding bodies of water and big fish. As you play, turn over the deeds and learn interesting facts and helpful fishing tips too!

link.value: Late for the Sky Production Company

item.description:
Wackelturm is a game of stacking wooden game pieces. There are yellow sticks and blue round pieces which can be stacked. The components to stack in a turn are decided by dice roll. You have to stack on top of previously placed items (by you and other players) so a tower emerges.
If the tower falls apart in your turn, you lose that round and get a red chip.
The first to have 3 red chips loses the game.

item.description:
The players accompany the dragon Lung, the dwarven girl Schwefelfell (Sulfurskin), the human boy Ben and a young woman on their journey to the border of the sky - the last place of refuge for dragons.

Players contribute to defeat the evil dragon Nesselbrand (Nettle) in this tactical movement game. How much did you contribute at game end, when the bad dragon is defeated?

Each player leads a paleontological excavation team, which consists of a researcher, a female assistant and a dog. Each team researches in different parts of a large excavation after different kinds of dinosaur skeletons. As soon as a researcher team excavated all parts of a dinosaur skeleton, it is exhibited in the museum. The player receives points of prestige, depending to on the size of the dinosaur.

item.description: This is a great game for toddlers that will help them learn shapes, animals, as well as colors. The object of the game is to match up three pairs of animals and place them into your rows in the ark. Each row has a different shape and color.

A free web-published card game based on GMT's SPQR. Each player uses a deck composed of cards representing ancient military units (infantry, cavalry) and special commands (flank, rally). Cards are drawn from these decks and played on a board representing the battlefield. The board is divided into three zones, the center and two wings. Units on the field may move, missile fire and shock with the enemy.

The game features a variety of historical armies and commanders, as well as fantasy forces.

A set of rules which can be played on any map showing political subdivisions. The players take turns placing one piece at a time on the mapboard in order to capture territories. Pieces may not be placed into enemy held spaces, and a player may not have more than three pieces in a single space. The diceless combat system requires you to establish a larger force in spaces adjacent to those occupied by the enemy. The game continues until both players pass, at which time the victor is the player who controls the most spaces.

The game was inspired by the 1983 SSI computer game Fortress, which was played on a 6x6 grid and limited to 21 turns.

6 dice are rolled and re-rolled, trying to get the correct colours to obtain dragon tiles from the display or to take them from other players. You can re-roll the dice several times but have to set at least one aside each time. 
The dragons are initially at risk from capture by other players but on your next turn you can set them into your secure layout. At the end you score points for having dragons of one colour or different dragons but with the same background landscape.

Part of the Schmidt Spiele Easy Play line.

item.description:
Learn the geography and customs of the people in this African adventure by all-terrain vehicle, crossing the different landscapes of the continent and living the most unexpected dangers.

It exalts the competitive spirit and capacity of planning to raise every race.

In the spring time as the sun rises and toads go on a journey, traffic becomes dangerous for them. In this game the toads walk on the motorway. We must save them with the help of the mole. There are tunnels under the motorway. If we are able to get all of the toads into a tunnel we win.

165 cards are mixed. The left neighbour always asks the question. On each card side a question is printed with three wrong answers. That is the joke of the thing, and this means for the players: listen exactly and watch out! With every correct answer there is a banana as reward. If an ape on the board is completely equipped with 6 bananas, the player who has that ape wins.

Thor is a revised version of Wildlife Safari (also known as Loco, Flinke Pinke, and Quandary). As in those versions, there are a number of "stocks" (here, God cards) each with a limited number of identical shares, and players are dealt cards which change the values of specific stocks. On a turn a player plays a value card (with only the last one played counting for each stock) and takes a stock, with a round ending when all the values have been played for a single stock. A number of rounds are played and scores totaled.

Thor differs from the other versions of the game in two respects: it accommodates up to 6 players (by adding an additional stock), and it includes a set of 14 action cards which can be used to affect play.

item.description:
Monopoly-like game with versions of different cities.

Players roll two dice. A red die and a white one. Players roll and move their pawns along the local different companies in a city. When a player lands on a company, he/she has to buy the property or pay the owner rent. If a player has a set of companies of the same color the rent rises.
Each turn a player has to take a card based on the roll of the red die. The game ends when one player owns all property.

A free promotional game from the chips brand Croky, combining roll-and-move with memory.

Each player plays a different parrot (that stands for one the the tastes).

Publisher nor year is indicated. However if I recall correctly, this game stems from the mid 1980s.

Simple Roll-and-Move childrens game based on the Sesame Street series. 
Players attempt to 'tik' (ie tick/touch) the character/color indicated by the drawn card.

Small travel basketball game. 3 standard dice (1 white "shooting" die, 2 blue defensive dice), and 2 red offensive dice with roman numerals 2-7. 1 red pawn to mark ball position. 1 dry erase marker to keep score on "board", 1 plastic coated card with image of basketball court.

Rolls of the dice determine court position, turnovers, blocked shots, rebounding, steals, fouls, and scoring.

In this game, players race to move four pawns from their starting positions around the board into their "Home Country." Basic gameplay resembles Pachisi or Sorry!, but there are a couple of twists. First of all, movement is controlled by a deck of standard playing cards (with some extra Aces and Kings) -- most cards move a pawn forward by their face value, but some have special powers (get a pawn out of the starting area, move multiple pawns, trade places, move backwards, etc.). Additionally, while the game can be played as a free-for-all, it is also possible for players to split into partnerships and aid their partners in the race to victory.

The game is subtitled "An International Card Game," featuring rules in eight different languages and decorating its board with the flags of many of the countries where it can be played.

The Hanging Gardens were one of the Seven Wonders of the Ancient World, but did they actually exist? Nothing remains of the reported splendor of the Gardens, which were built for the eyes of Queen Amyitis.

In The Hanging Gardens, players are landscape architects who attempt to reestablish the beauty and splendor of the original Hanging Gardens. Since there is no exact reference to follow, players create designs according to their own tastes.

During the game, players acquire building cards, which they place in their play areas. Card follows card with magnificent buildings, sparkling fountains, and exotic plants, as the players work to rebuild the legendary Gardens. At game end, the Queen will reward the victory palm to the player whose work on the Gardens most impresses Her Highness.

item.description:
(Taken from the publisher's site):

The purpose of the game is to place the six pieces of the puzzle on the card so that a continuous path is formed by the clear parts from the starting point to the final point.

Each challenge contains a country map with 5 pieces of information about the country: 

 Country's flag 
 Country's currency 
 A general trivia fact about the country 
 Capital city 
 A famous landmark

This game book consists of a set of divisional level miniature wargame rules and a highly political campaign system. The players all play on the Union side, in the positions of Banks and his divisional commanders.

The campaign system is designed to generate battles, either by player initiative or automated Southern attacks. The players choose each turn to train their troops, administer conquered areas, indulge in 'politicking' in Washington, write or execute orders, request reinforcements or send them to McLellan's army in the Peninsula. If no Union forces contact the Confederate forces, the latter will make contact.

The miniature combat rules are aimed to portray small battles 2-6 brigades on each side) in a short game. They emphasize terrain, reserves, command ability and troop quality.

It includes:
The Gamebook
A campaign map of the Shenandoah Valley
Campaign game unit counters
Campaign game money
Campaign game tables

(Description taken from their homepage):

The pyramids of Egypt are among the most enduring and mysterious symbols of the ancient Egyptian civilization. The pyramids are considered to be one of the seven wonders of the world. The leaders of this ancient time-the pharaohs were clever strategists who would use all manner of tactics to ensure that their dynasties remained in power.

Two powerful symbols of ancient Egypt; the pyramid and the scarab are combined to create a unique game that will challenge you to think like the pharaohs.

“Battle of the Pyramids” is a strategic game for two players that combine the principles of planning, strategic thinking, memory and surprise.

Not for the faint hearted Battle of the Pyramids challenges you to be the first to have your pyramids reach the other-side unscathed. Conceal the scarabs within your pyramids to impede your opponent’s assault. Plan your strategy and attempt to get your opponent to reveal their pyramids hidden secrets.

An LPS bonus mini-game for two-players simulating the fighting around El Alamein station from 1 July to 27 July 1942. Each turn represents three days of combat, and each hex is about four miles across.
 Low density counter mix, ratio combat results table, supply, leaders, weather, air support, recon screening units, minefields and a special 88 Flak unit make for an interesting mix of mechanics.

item.description:
From publishers website:

"You are invited to the party! This memory-matching game will engage children with a charming array of colorful and crazy hats. Pick a pair, build a stack and win the game! Hat Stackers Party includes 11 X 17" double-sided folding magnetic game board, 40 chunky foam magnet game pieces, and full-color illustrated instruction booklet with easy-to-follow rules."

item.description: Syl-la-blesis the game that encourages you to think big. Choose a bigger word to get more points, but spell it right or you score zero! "Thesaurus" and "Spelling Bee" cards test your vocabulary and spelling skills. This is a unique game for playing with varied ages, because you set your own point goals--for individuals or the group--before you start the game. Tested by the Canadian Toy Testing Council and recipient of the 2007 Seal of Approval from The National Parenting Center.

"Be quick because each player only has one minute to “play on words” and win the challenge! Set the timer and, before it sounds, write as many connecting words as possible using only the letters on the eight cubes shown. The more words “played on” and the more letters used, the higher the score. Challenge friends or yourself with the solitaire version. Play On Words includes a built-in electronic timer. "

24 cards are distributed evenly to all fellow players.
The player with the “start” - card puts these on the table and begins the round, by pulling a card of any fellow player. Afterwards this Turn player is now to pull with a fellow player etc.
If he pulls a point card, he puts it wordless to its other cards. He must show an action card and had to fulfill it immediately. As soon as a player pulls the “stop” - card, the round is terminated, and everyone recounts the points, which he holds straight on the hand.

(Translated from the Japanese rulebook)
In this game, the players are owners of inns, and the goal is to get as many staying guests, earning the most money in a set period of time.
But it's not easy preparing rooms for all those people who have come to the festival in town. Among the normal guests like travelers and merchants, there is the King, the General and even assassins and Demon Lord! It's a chaotic mix of everything.
Each guest has their own condition for staying the night and paying the room. Some are content if you serve them tasty food, some look only for good service and some are looking for a good fight…
If you can't please the guest, not only will you not get paid, but you have to pay instead, so you'll have to be careful which guests you accommodate. You can push dangerous guests to your neighbour's door, but if you're not careful, you might get one yourself!
The character the players play all have different areas they are good at and bad at. And they, too, are former adventurers, so they have individual skills to attract or deter guests. The one who uses these skills the best, gets the most content customers and earns the most money during the festival will be declared the winner.

(Translated from the Japanese rule book)
In this game, players cooperate in order to defeat huge monsters. All damage dealt to the monster is directly converted into Victory Points, and the one with the most VPs when the third monster is defeated, is declared the winner.
But it is not an easy task to deal damage to these huge creatures. If you're too far away, you can't deal any damage at all. In order to deal damage, and earn points, you need to get close to the monster, and run the risk of taking damage yourself.
And dealing damage isn't the only thing you must be careful about. The other players are aiming at your back. They might try to push you to the front line. If you're pushed to the front, and the monster gets you, all your points are halved!
Seeing to that the leading player gets nicely defeated, and still having cards left to deal some damage to the monster, will make you the winner.

(Translated from the Japanese rulebook):
The goal of this game is to collect the most money for your marriage. But it's not just any money. It's the treasure of the dragon that you (think you) defeated.
As the players enter the dragon's lair and start collecting treasure, the dragon will eventually awaken. The players must then run away from the maddened dragon, while holding onto as much treasure as they can. But if they have a lot of treasure, they'll be slowed down. If the dragon gets them, not only will they get hurt, but they'll also drop the treasures, one after the other! So stack you items carefully, equip and re-equip, trip the other player's legs as much as you can and run for your life.
The player who gets out with the most treasure is declared the winner

Link your stones to gain points. 
The object of the game is to gain the most points by forming links between your stones. Players take turns placing a stone. If the stone can be linked to any other friendly stone(s) in one of the eight directions (north, south, east, west, northeast, northwest, southeast, southwest), then a line of friendly pebbles is placed on all spaces along the paths connecting the stones. A connection cannot be made if an enemy stone lies along the path to the friendly stone.

The score corresponds to the number of pebbles owned by each player. The game ends when there are no remaining moves. The player with the most pebbles wins.

You don't have to wait till the stars are right! If you want to summon your favorite Mythos creature, make the stars OK yourself!

The players first create their own star diagram on the piece of paper and then play various cards to recreate it on the board.

Good clean fun for the whole Whateley family.

The emperor and its royal household walk proudly in the palace garden. Everyone made the cunning weavers manufacture a marvelous dress for him. By great fear to be considered as too stupid neither the emperor nor its officials dare to throw a view on their shade. There they can recognize that they are naked in reality. Fortunately a small boy, who sits in a tree in the palace garden, and the players don't let themselves deceive by the stupid trick of the weavers. Gradually the boy and the players hold the naked image before the faces of the vain emperor and its attendants. A little to search they must thereby, and the cunning weavers try likewise to donate confusion. Who finds three of the twelve naked images first, exposed the treacherous weavers and wins the game.

A fascinating game of skill and chance playing two of everyone's favorite card games-cribbage and poker. Where the players decide whether to play out their hand as a cribbage game or slip into high stakes poker.

The object of the game is collect the most chips in a variety of ways. By means of green Cribble cards. By strategic use of the Blue Cribble cards. By avoiding penalty cards and red pegs holes. By pegging around the Cribble track to be the first to reach the last hole and collect the Cribbage pot. And by call Cribble to play high-stakes poker for individual poker pots.

name.value: Reader's Digest National Word Power Challenge

item.description:
The box that I received is "Set 1" in the official card game series. It contains three decks of 64 cards each: Over the Rainbow, Speaking Out, and Lost in Space.

Each deck is a themed game of Go Fish containing 16 sets of 4 cards each. However, the cards contain advanced vocabulary words from Reader's Digest Word Power columns. The four facets of each card are: Definition and Part of Speech, Word Origin, Synonyms, Fill in the Blank, the latter of which is an example sentence in which a blank indicates where the word would go.

On your turn, you ask for a card whose [insert facet] is [insert facet's description], e.g. "I would like a card whose synonyms are abandon, abdicate, discard, throw away." If the player has a "Jettison" card, he gives it up. The rest of the rules are Go Fish.

The box includes a supplementary color guide with pictures and further explanations for each word.

name.value: Salvanèl: flight from the enchanted wood

item.description:
Who is the Salvanèl?
The Salvanèl is a goblin that frequently appears in the legends of Trentino, in northern Italy. Until not many decades ago, in every valley you could find someone who said they had seen the Salvanèl, even though actually encountering him was extremely unlikely.
They described him as a small man, boyish-looking, and always with some red feature on him: a hat, clothes or hair.

This time the Salvanèl, running to and fro, has left his magical tracks everywhere. Anyone who treads on them by mistake is bound to get lost - and after much wandering, finds himself back where he started. Now you are lost in the wood too!
To get back home you must make three good moves to reconstruct a path that will take you out of the wood. But the goblin will also help you, if you meet him!

At the beginning of every turn, the guide picks a colored card. This card has two effects:
1-The Salvanèl immediately moves toward the border indicated by the card, and if he meets a player... He immediately gains an extra turn!
2-The player indicated by the card plays his turn... And if he meets the Salvanèl... He plays again!

In every turn, players can use one of these moves:
1-Spin:choose a tile and rotate it in any direction you like
2-Puff of Wind: move one or more tiles of a horizontal or vertical line
3-Jump: move your token from the tile where it is to another one next to it.

The first player who jumps out of any tile on the side of his colour wins!

item.description:
This game covers the Battle for Berlin, and is designed by the same game designer of The Battle for Iwo Jima. The game includes one A2-sized map of Berlin, divided into areas in a manner similar to Storm over Arnhem, as well as one A3-sized reproduction of the map. This is similar in nature to the one featured at the back of the rulebook in Storm over Arnhem, and presumably to be used for the same purpose. The game also includes 81 counters.

This game was designed by Works-Zero (www.works-zero.com).

name.value: The Story of Genghis' Conquest of the West

item.description:
This game covers Genghis Khan's invasion of Central Asia against the Khwarazm (Khorezm) Empire from 1219-1221. It appears to be a strategic-level game, unlike the accompanying Temujin's Battles.

The game includes 1 A2-sized map with 81 counters.

This game was designed by Works-Zero (www.works-zero.com).

Tactical-level game with three scenarios, each with a map.

The game includes 3 different A3-sized maps and 116 counters.

This game was designed by Works-Zero.
Each player tries to eat full with cards of food points so that it can oversleep the winter in its hiding place. Who gets over the “winter sleep” without starving first, wins.

From the One Page Wars game series.

"RftE attempts to simulate the conflict between rebels revolting and attempting to take control of their nation from a foreign power. In this fantasy banana republic the nation of Britain has held control for the past 115 years. Now the rebels have started to advance from the north towards the major hub of Port Hanley."

This small format game is played on a narrow L-shaped map. Victory goes to the player who controls most of the seven cities on the board after twenty turns. The British units include Royal Marines, Light Infantry, Challenger tanks, and Puma helicopters.

Content:
48 picture cards

As time runs all players try to fit cards in their hands at the same time. It is important to catch the cards as fast as lightning. The winner is the player with the most caught cards.

item.description:
Spion im Werk or Spy in the facory was produced by Adam Opel AG in order to encourage the employees to communicate more with each other. The Goal of the game is to catch a spy, that has sneaked off into the Opel factory in Rüsselsheim, Germany. There are two teams: One plays the spy and the others play a team trying to catch the spy, but the spy has some sneaky skills to avoid being caught by the other team, If he succeeds in stealling a specific amount of secret files from the factory, the spy wins.

The game mechanic is a mixture of roll & move and answering questions.

This unique variation on Backgammon called Zarsiz Tavla in Turkish has no luck to it. It uses a unique system of players alternating turns picking one die facing, and their opponent picking the second, in order to determine moves. The end result is a player is left with a die facing they picked, and the other their opponent picked. Players are allowed to use the die they picked twice, as a roll, several times during the game to act as a rolling doubles.

Full Information on the game can be obtained here:
http://zarsiztavla.gop.edu.tr/index-e.htm

The rules are under how to play.

item.description: Each of the two or 4 players chooses a color and puts his 5 pawns on the start fields of the same color. The point is to bring the own pawns across the board to the opposite finish fields. The player who is there with his 5 pawns wins the game.
A quiz-game from the fifties - the player gets the question card. Either the player who is asked, the questioning player or the referee can answer it.

Pay attention to your own moves - as well as to the move of your co-players. Because only the player who is able to make an error free move at last can win.
The difficulty consists of the fact that no pawn of the same color may stand left, right, above, down or diagonally beside the set cone.
Ab, durch die Mitte is an easily understandable tactics game for 2 or 4 people, where the point is, to be the first to have their pawns disappear through the hole in the center of the game box.

A trivia game based on the traffic safety campaign "Ich Fahr' Fair" (roughly: "I drive considerately"). Players earn puzzle pieces by answering multiple-choice, traffic trivia questions in six categories. Correct answers allow a player to roll again and continue their turn.

Contents; Game board, 6 wooden car pawns, question cards with answers, 6 puzzles with 6 pieces, rules and a dice. 
Note; the game is only available in a German language version.

Basic Tic-Tac-Toe only you must correctly answer a Bible trivia question--which category (out of nine choices) is listed on a movable/variable chart under the tic-tac-toe board--for the space you want to occupy.

Clever board/component setup makes it a convenient game to play.

Love playing the classic mystery-solving game but don't have time to play the original version? This express edition delivers a burst of fun in 20 minutes! Roll the dice, then make a suggestion. Peek at cards or the case file for extra clues. Includes rules for two ways to play, anytime, anywhere!

Part of the Hasbro Express Line.

item.description:
COMPONENTS
20 Ship tiles (4 aircraft carriers, 4 submarines, 4 destroyers, 4 battleships, 4 patrol boats)
8 attack dice

Battleship Express comes with two different games: The Captain’s Game and The Admiral’s Game. The Captain's Game ignore the ships powers on the cards.

Each player receives 5 ship tiles, one of each ship: Battleship, Destroyer, Aircraft Carrier, Submarine, Patrol Boat. Each player places them in front of them in any order to make up their fleet.

On a player's turn they choose one of the ships in their Fleet to attack with and move it to the front of their line. Next the player chooses a ship of an opposing player to attack. The attacking player can only choose one of the first 2 ships in the line to attack. The attacking ship tile shows how many dice to roll. Roll that number of dice and check for hits. Each of the 8 dice is the same. 5 of the sides match the colors of the 5 ships, and the sixth side is a “burst” or “wild”. IF the player does not sink it, the dice are passed to the next player.

Set aside any hits and then re-roll based on the attacking ship’s powers. Once the number of hits equals or exceeds the defense number on the ship that's defending, it is sunk removed from play and the attacking player gets a point. The first player to an agreed number of set points wins. Here’s a breakdown of the individual ship powers:


 Battleship: Declare target. Roll all 8 dice a total of 4 times. Bursts do not count as hits.
 Destroyer: Declare target. Roll 6 dice a total of 2 times. Bursts count as 2 hits.
 Aircraft Carrier: Roll 6 dice THEN declare your target, then roll 1 more time. Bursts count as 1 hit. The Aircraft Carrier can also attack from anywhere in your line, so you don’t have to move it to the front where it is vulnerable.
 Submarine: Roll 3 dice a total of one time. A single Burst will sink whatever you are attacking. Submarines can attack any ship at any place in a Fleet.
 Patrol Boat: Roll 5 dice a total of 3 times. Bursts count as 1 hit.


Part of the Hasbro Express Line.

item.description:
Following France’s glorious victory against the combined Austro-Russian armies at Austerlitz the previous December, the Prussians have finally come off the fence and declared war against Napoleon. As both sides maneuver, uncertain of the location or center of gravity of the opposing army, they met in a dramatic double battle on the fields of both Jena and Auerstadt.

Can the heirs of Frederick the Great maintain their composure and cohesion long enough to teach the haughty French a lesson, or will Napoleon and his Marshals ride on to ever greater glory?

With only modest complexity and a focused scope employing low unit density on the map (20 pieces or less) and dramatic, fast playing turns, it is the addition of ‘story-driven’ random event cards and night game turns providing the operational pauses and “friction of war” that gives players a great feel for the parry-and-thrust of a Napoleonic campaign as the armies close for battle. Scale: Each unit is 1 corps, each hex is about 1000 meters, and each turn is roughly 3.5 day hours (or 10 night hours).

Game Components:
• One 8-page, color instructions booklet, with Standard and Optional rules included
• 1-page sheet of Exclusive rules
• 40 color, die-cut 5/8” mounted game pieces
• 12 random event cards
• One 11” x 17” color game map
• One 8.5” x 11” color player aid sheet

item.description:
Appeared in the August 1991 issue of Games magazine, page 50.

This two player strategy game is based on trying to cross the board with your pieces to get into a goal area, removing it. The first player to get 3 of his pieces into the goal wins.

The unusual mechanic to this game is that you can move any piece on your turn, yours or your opponent's, any unblocked distance on a line. If you move your pieces, the end space must have a different number of adjacent pieces from the space where it started, while if you move an opposing piece, it must end adjacent to the same number of pieces.

A simple board game, similar to Sorry! or Parchisi. Movement takes place with a roll of the dice.
The game comes in two phases. First, players progress through "Desert Shield", in which they collect cards that can later be used to defeat threats. Second, they move to "Desert Storm", in which they use their cards to overcome obstacles on the board. When a player reaches the middle of the board, they have won the game and liberated Kuwait. 
If you encounter an obstacle that there is no card for, then you must restart Desert Storm. If this happens three times in a row, then Desert Shield must be repeated as well. There are also locations on the board that will send you back to the start.

Dresda is a ‘fast-play’ fantasy battle skirmish system designed for small numbers of troops yet involving more than a little role-playing on the part of the players. Indeed, unlike many conventional wargames with little or no ‘role-playing’ element, in Dresda you are your units' Commander in the field, and you not only have the responsibility of commanding the unit in battle, but also the headaches of paying your troops, buying their equipment and generally trying to improve your (and their) financial position.

Dresda is a scenario driven game, not points based one. This means that careful thought needs to be given to the designing of scenarios by the GM. So, although you can line up your troops on opposite sides of the table and simply advance until you bump into each other in the centre, you'll find this isn't really much fun, and you'll quickly find that your games will be much more enjoyable if you (and/or a good GM) put some effort into designing an interesting or challenging scenario.

Of course, it also helps to create a feeling of unit continuity by treating your unit as a group of individuals rather than disposable 'cannon (or halberd)-fodder'. Name each of them, decide what they like to eat, drink and how they feel about their Mum, and suddenly you can see them as characters in a role-playing game, not just as troops in a ‘one-off’ wargame.

Over a number of games you'll see your unit develop, watch their fortunes wax and wane and individual characters come and go. Eventually you'll find that some of these factors will start to dictate your actions on the battlefield, for instance you may see ‘heroic’ traits develop in one character or cowardly traits in another as the miniatures begin to become characters in their own right, and not just anonymous lumps of painted white metal.

The Aim of the Game

The basic aim of Dresda is to raise a small unit of fighters, fight battles and get rich!

Unfortunately, whilst this basic aim is simple, it isn't necessarily easy. What's more, this is likely to be a more 'hands-on' experience than you may be used to, even in skirmish wargaming. That's because you, the Player, will take on the role of your unit's Commander, and will be represented on the battlefield by a miniature figure!

From the instructions: Fetch the Ink! was devised to give an entertaining insight into printshop routine, which can be pretty hectic at times! In view of the tight delivery deadlines involved there is often a fine line between human error and superhuman achievement.

"Ink is a basic essential for printing, so the winner of the game is the player whose team is the first to reach the coveted ink buckets in the centre of the board."

Each player starts off at the printing press in the colored corresponding corner and strives to reach the matching ink bucket in the middle of the board.

There are two circuits linked by four cross paths and a player must try to reach the colour spectrum via the line of squares in his or her colour.

Clubhouse Golf Dice Game loosely simulates a round of golf through the same scoring system - the lower the number of strokes, the better your score. The game comes with 5 dice: A white Tee die, a light green Fairway (F) die, a blue Water (W) die, a yellow Sand (S) die and a dark green putting (G for Green) die. Except for the putting die, the dice have letters on them indicating the next die to be cast. The putting die has numbers on it.

Each hole, a player starts by rolling the Tee die (the first stroke). Subsequently, the player rolls the next die indicated by the previous die, adding one stroke to their score for each die rolled. However, when the Water die is rolled, the player adds 2 strokes instead. When the Green (G) is rolled, the player rolls the putting die and adds the number rolled to his/her score - the hole then ends for that player and his/her score is the number of strokes played. Players can play 18 holes for a full round of golf. The lowest total score wins.

It's easier to get a hole-in-one in this game than in real golf - roll 'G' on the Tee die, followed by a roll of '0' on the putting die.
For 2-4 players or teams interested in the trivia of Tacoma Washington. Comes with a colorful board and trivia cards. For Ages 13 and up
For Hannah Montana fans Ages 7 and up. Customized Uno version that comes with two special cards that change the game play. 112 cards with lots of pictures from the show.
The player who returns to the castle with his two knights and brings the ring of Isabella with him/her wins the game.

Content:
board, 4 wooden dwarves, 8 jewels, 4 "rope" stones, 1 die

The game idea is for your dwarf to cross over the canyon using the log , then to unload the jewel, run back, pick up the second jewel,balance it across the canyon once again and unload it a second time and finally to run back to the starting place. The whole thing done as fast as possible and without falling down.

This boardgame simulates the life of a Mary Kay sales consultant, as she goes from consultant to National Sales Director and earns the highest possible amount of money.

The game includes the board, 4 markers, 1 die, playing money(Pinks), 200 Recruit Cards, 25 Consultant Cards, 20 Director Cards, 75 Offspring Director Cards.

There are minor obstacles to overcome, and players must recruit and sell, win contests, attend the Seminar, and eventually earn a Mercedes and attain the position of National Sales Director.
